Award.AwardTitle: BPEC: Collaborative Research: Creating Personalized Learning Pathways by Managing Cognitive Load

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Washington University, in collaboration with the St. Louis Science Center will develop and evaluate a computer programing environment that uses personalized learning pathways to better engage and support young learners. In both formal and informal education settings, examples of solved problems are an important learning resource, enabling self-teaching, and supporting the inherent heterogeneity found in classrooms. Recent studies of programmers at varying experience levels revealed that selecting and adapting example code shared on the web is often used to support just in time learning and to access infrequently used techniques. However, while examples can be powerful learning tools, they must be well-matched to the learner's experience level and learning preferences. The project staff will develop computer algorithms that predict what future problems and examples will maximize learning for a specific learner.

Research on learning via examples has demonstrated that by controlling the cognitive load for a given learner through the selection and presentation of examples and their related practice problems, it is possible to improve learner's success on near and far transfer tasks. This proposal hypothesizes that by carefully controlling the cognitive load, it will be possible to construct personalized learning pathways that help a learner to efficiently move from a novice understanding to mastery of a concept.
This project aims to answer the following questions:
1) Is it possible to predict the perceived cognitive load for a future problem, given a learner's history and use this to select an appropriate next problem for that learner?
2) What are the factors of a learner's history that are most predictive of the perceived cognitive load for a future problem?
3) Is it possible to effectively use the predicted cognitive load to construct personalized learning pathways for an individual learner?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Code puzzles are an increasingly possible way to introduce students to computer science and programming. Yet, current puzzle-based systems take a “one size fits all” approach in which all learners progress through the same content. In this project, we explored the creation of a personalized approach to code puzzle selection based on predicting perceived cognitive load. Cognitive load is a measure of how difficult a given learner finds a task. It can vary based on the learner’s background and abilities, the difficulty of the learning task, and the characteristics of the ways in which the learning task is presented. Using this award, we have made the following contributions:

  1. We have created the first (that we are aware of) technique that is able to predict cognitive load and use that prediction to personalize learning. To do this, we built a machine learning model that predicts cognitive load for an unseen code puzzle using the learner behaviors on previously completed puzzles. This type of model enables a new approach to personalization and provides example strategies for how to capture characteristics of learner behavior that may be valuable for future systems. Our cognitive load model demonstrates the ability to shift cognitive load based on learner. Further, while our final evaluation did not demonstrate associated learning gains, we have identified a new need: research on understanding the appropriate levels for cognitive load. Our results preliminarily suggest that it is better to aim for puzzles that are perceived as relatively easy, but also identify an opportunity to explore policies for varying perceived load over time. 

  2. Studying what the cognitive load model has learned about learner behavior enabled us to explore what kinds of changes can be made to puzzles to customize difficulty and the relative impact of those changes. Our results suggest that locking some pieces of the code puzzle together (reducing the number of pieces to be placed) is an effective strategy for modifying puzzle difficulty. However, we think this approach can be used to explore other potential mechanisms for modifying difficulty that can provide opportunities to adapt challenge-levels with finer granularity.

  3. Further, our model suggests that the most predictive features for future cognitive load are ones associated with germane load invested in past puzzles. While prior work in Cognitive Load Theory has posited that cognitive load associated with germane load can assist in future learning situations, our model provides confirmation of this in both positive and negative cases. In other words, past puzzles solved through investing in understanding predict lower cognitive load and past puzzles solved through guessing predict higher load.

Broader Impacts:

Over the course of this grant, we have worked with nearly 500 young students, more than half of whom were underrepresented in computer science (either female, minority, or both). As part of our summer camp studies, we additionally developed curricular materials to teach other aspects of programming and animation creation in Looking Glass and other tools. These materials were then shared via a teacher workshop hosted in conjunction with Washington University’s Institute for School Partnership. 

Finally, the Looking Glass system is available for download at lookingglass.wustl.edu and includes puzzle support developed in this grant.
